In four portions, BPUB203 addresses how businesses interact with political and regulatory institutions, the law, and the public. The first portion analyzes the economic rationale for legislation and regulation in the presence of market failures. The second portion examines the messier realities of “political economy” and the actual making of laws and regulations by imperfect politicians and regulators. Third, the course addresses more squarely the ways that firms and managers can and do shape their nonmarket environments, as well tools to help managers think through related nonmarket decisions. In the fourth portion we will cover topics in financial regulation. 

Overall, students directed very little in their reviews to the course content. One reported that the slides used in the class were “very difficult to use as a studying supplement.” 

Tobacman received poor reviews from the class. In terms of his lectures, many students said that he seemed “disinterested in teaching this course” and “did not communicate the subject matter well.” Many students took issue with his refusal to discuss the answers to the practice exam during the office hours, though they believed the other BPUB203 professor had discussed them. 

Students felt that the exams were “not indicative of what we learned” and poorly structured. A few mentioned that the grading of the exams seemed “arbitrary.” Most students took this course to fulfill the Societal Environment requirement in Wharton.

The first portion analyzes the economic rationale for legislation and regulation in the presence of market failures. One said that the course content was “interesting” but another said that it “tried to cover many disconnected subjects” so they perceived the course to be disorganized. Another student said that “the differences in knowledge level in the class” due to students coming from all four class years should be taken into account by the professor. 

Professor Anagol’s teaching received mixed reviews. They felt that he “was generally well prepared for lecture.” Some students said he “had some difficult conveying the subject matter,” but was “enthusiastic about the material” so they appreciated his effort. 

Students reported that the exams were “difficult,” and a few mentioned that “the readings were unnecessarily long.” Most students took this course to fulfill the Societal Environment requirement in Wharton.
